question: This respondent is ([See Blaise Specifications for SecA.ContinuInterview.A019_RAge assignment]) years old. INTERVIEWER: If R is age 75 or older and you are assigned to disability vignettes, do not administer the leave-behind. Enter 4 to complete the interview. Otherwise continue below. Lastly, I have a short questionnaire that I would like to leave with (you/ (Respondents First Name)) to fill out. We would appreciate it if (you/ (Respondents First Name)) would complete this questionnaire at (your/his/her) earliest convenience and send it back to our office in this self-addressed envelope. If (you/ (Respondents First Name)) (have/has) any questions about the form or how to complete it, feel free to call our toll free number, which is listed in the questionnaire.
User Note: Inadvertantly, both types of questionnaires were sent to 11 respondents. We have retained the data for these cases.

Blue= Other than the conditions explicitly mentioned, you should imagine the individual is in reasonably good health. Red= Other than the conditions explicitly mentioned, you should imagine the individual is like yourself.

description: LIMITS ON WORK B/C OF HEALTH PROB
question: During our interview with you we asked you whether you have any impairment or health problem that limits the kind or amount of paid work you can do. The purpose of the following questions is to explore the meaning of your answers. The first question is very similar to the one we asked before. In the interview, we asked you to respond with a simple yes or no. This time, we would like you to respond using a five-point scale from 'not at all limited' to 'cannot do any work.' Example: 1a. To what extent are you limited in the kind or amount of work you can do because of an impairment or health problem?

We would now like to give you a number of examples of (men/women) with some health problems. We would like you to indicate the extent to which you think these (men/women) would be limited in the kind or amount of work they can do. In terms of their age, their education, Other than the conditions explicitly mentioned, you should imagine the individual is in reasonably good health. Please give us your judgment on how limited these people are in the kind or amount of work they can do. (Tim/Mary) generally enjoys (his/her) work. (He/She) gets depressed every three weeks for a day or two and loses interest in what (he/she) usually enjoys, but is able to carry on with (his/her) day-to-day activities on the job.
(Jim/Ann) enjoys work very much. (He/She) feels that (he/she) is doing a very good job and is optimistic about the future.

(Bob/Nancy) has mood swings on the job. When (he/she) gets depressed, everything (he/she) does at work is an effort for (him/her) and (he/she) no longer enjoys (his/her) usual activities at work. These mood swings are not predictable and occur two or three times during a month.

(Frank/Barb) feels worried all the time. (He/She) gets depressed once a week at work for a couple of days in a row, thinking about what could go wrong and that (his/her) boss will disapprove of (his/her) condition. But (he/she) is able to come out of this mood if (he/she) concentrates on something else.

description: AFFECT- DEPRESSED MOST OF THE TIME
question: (Gary/Kathleen) feels depressed most of the time. (He/She) weeps frequently at work and feels hopeless about the future. (He/She) feels that (he/she) has become a burden on (his/her) co-workers and that (he/she) would be better dead.

description: PAIN- OCCASIONAL BACK PAIN AT WORK
question: (Michael/Sue) occasionally feels back pain at work, but this has not happened for the last several months now. If (he/she) feels back pain, it typically lasts only for a few days.

description: PAIN- STIFFNESS IN BACK AT WORK
question: (Carl/Carol) suffers from back pain that causes stiffness in (his/her) back, especially at work, but is relieved with low doses of medication. (He/She) does not have any pains other than this generalized discomfort.
(Matthew/Ruth) has almost constant pain in (his/her) back and this sometimes prevents (him/her) from doing (his/her) work.

(George/Linda) has back pain that makes changes in body position while (he/she) is working very uncomfortable. (He/She) is unable to stand or sit for more than half an hour. Medicines decrease the pain a little, but it is there all the time and interferes with (his/her) ability to carry out even day-to- day tasks at work.

description: PAIN-BACK AND LEG PAIN ALMOST ALWAYS
question: (Mark/Jane) has pain in (his/her) back and legs, and the pain is present almost all the time. It gets worse while (he/she) is working. Although medication helps, (he/she) feels uncomfortable when moving around, holding and lifting things at work.
(Peter/Karen) is very active and fit. (He/She) takes aerobic classes 3 times a week.

description: CVD- HEART PROBLEMS IN THE PAST
question: (Jacob/Lori) has had heart problems in the past and (he/she) has been told to watch (his/her) cholesterol level. Sometimes if (he/she) feels stressed at work (he/she) feels pain in (his/her) chest and occasionally in (his/her) arms.

(Paul/Beth)s family has a history of heart problems. (His/Her) father died of a heart attack when (Paul/Beth) was still very young. The doctors have told (Paul/Beth) that (he/she) is at severe risk of having a serious heart attack (himself/herself) and that (he/she) should avoid strenuous physical activity or stress. (He/She) sometimes feels severe pain in (his/her) chest and arms, and suffers from dizziness, fainting, sweating, nausea or shortness of breath.

(Tom/Diane) has been diagnosed with high blood pressure. (His/Her) blood pressure goes up quickly if (he/she) feels under stress. (Tom/Diane) does not exercise much and is overweight. Life can sometimes can be hectic for (him/her). (He/She) does not get along with (his/her) boss very well.
(Dan/Judy) has undergone triple bypass heart surgery. (He/She) is a heavy smoker and still experiences severe chest pain sometimes.

Q24. Think of this ladder [diagram of ladder is presented] as representing where people stand in our society. At the top of the ladder are the people who are the best off - those who have the most money, most education, and best jobs. At the bottom are the people who are the worst off - who have the least money, least education, and the worst jobs or no jobs. The higher up you are on this ladder, the closer you are to the people at the very top and the lower you are, the closer you are to the people at the very bottom. Think of this ladder as representing where people stand in our society. At the top of the ladder are the people who are the best off - those who have the most money, most education, and best jobs. At the bottom are the people who are the worst off - who have the least money, least education, and the worst jobs or no jobs. The higher up you are on this ladder, the closer you are to the people at the very top and the lower you are, the closer you are to the people at the very bottom.
